CALLAWAY GOLF STAFF PROFESSIONAL HALL OF FAME ENSHRINES HAWAIâIâS TOM FREESTONE - The Golf Wire Skip to primary navigation Skip to main content Skip to primary sidebar Skip to footer Advertise â¢ Subscribe â¢ Contact The Golf Wire Covering the business of golf! MENU MENU Apparel Business Courses Equipment People Podcasts Jobs Search Close CALLAWAY GOLF STAFF PROFESSIONAL HALL OF FAME ENSHRINES HAWAIâIâS TOM FREESTONE June 10, 2025 Twitter Facebook Pinterest Email Ocean Course At HÅkÅ«ala Gm Accepts Illustrious Award During Surprise Ceremony CARLSBAD , Calif. â In a surprise ceremony at Callaway Golfâs corporate headquarters in March, Tom Freestone was presented with the highest honor that the manufacturer can bestow upon a staff member: enshrinement into the Callaway Golf Staff Professional Hall of Fame. The PGA General Manager of the Ocean Course at HÅkÅ«ala on Kauaâi was surrounded by industry peers and family members when he was informed of the honor. âSimply put, I am filled with a tremendous gratitude,â remarked Freestone, a 13-year Callaway Golf Staff Professional. âCallaway has done great things across their storied history in the sport. Their decision to âgrow the familyâ with my inclusion into their Hall of Fame was a tremendous honor that I will forever cherish.â Freestone was honored for his long-standing commitment to the brand, offering world-class instruction, quality club fittings, hosting championship events and many other redeeming qualities. Following the ceremony, inductees were treated to a round of golf and deep dive into the brand. Highlights included learning about the companyâs history, success across the amateur and professional levels, pushing the limits of accuracy (dispersion ratios, dimple patterns, balanced cores, etc.) and upcoming AI technology. âWe had the wonderful experience of meeting Randy Rubin (Director, Strategic Partnerships, Callaway Golf), Joel Rump (Sr. Director, Sales, Training and Staff Relations), Corey Newman (Sr. Manager, Custom Fittings and Training) and many others,â reminisced Freestone. âThese guys are the best at what they do. They design, fit and tweak equipment for the worldâs best players. Personally interacting with them and learning how they hone their skills was gratifying.â Callaway Golfâs long-standing relationship with Troon began when Dana Garmany, Troon Founder and now Board Member, purchased the management companyâs first rental set of clubs for Troon North. This laid a strong, global foundation for how relationships can be created between manufacturers and staff professionals. âWe work in a customer-driven industry,â continued Freestone. When a guestâs club fitting goes well, that deepens our relationship with them. When the guest is happy, that makes us happy.â The Ocean Course at HÅkÅ«ala operates as an âohana (family), literally and figuratively. To this day, generations of family members proudly work together at the club on Kauaâi. Furthermore, the entire teaching staff is aligned with Callaway Golf. The manufacturer operates in a similar way. âCallaway Golf has grown as an âohana too. Chip Brewer (CEO, Topgolf Callaway Brands) came from Adams Golf. Roger Cleveland, the highly respected engineer and club designer who founded Cleveland Golf in the 1970s, also joined Callaway Golf. I was honored to join this elite group of visionaries that I have a lot of respect for,â reflected Freestone. Most recently, Freestone earned the âLow PGA Memberâ award following his four-day finish in the 2025 Mid-Pacific Open on Oahu. Under Freestoneâs leadership, the Ocean Course at HÅkÅ«alaâs teaching staff offers game-improvement offerings for keiki through seniors, including programming from the Aloha Section PGA, First Tee Hawaiâi, Operations36, Indigo Golf Partners, Troon and more. The club is also equipped year-round with a Callaway Golf fitting cart and Trackman, allowing any guests to receive a custom club fitting at a momentâs notice. To learn more, visit www.golfhokuala.com About Ocean Course at HÅkÅ«ala Home to the longest continuous stretch of oceanfront holes in the state of Hawaiâi, the Ocean Course was named one of the âWorldâs Most Beautiful Golf Coursesâ by MSN Travel. The 18-hole golf course is part of Timbers Kauaâi Ocean Club & Residences, a private residential club which opened in 2018 on the islandâs southeast coast. Timbers Kauaâi sits on a 450-acre natural amphitheater and offers unobstructed views of the Pacific Ocean, Kalapaki Bay and HÄâupu Mountain Range. About Troon The Ocean Course at HÅkÅ«ala is managed by Indigo Sports, a Troon company. Headquartered in Scottsdale, Ariz., Troon is the worldâs largest golf and golf-related hospitality management company providing services at 940-plus locations in 45-plus states and 40-plus countries, including operational responsibility for 575-plus 18-hole equivalent golf courses. In addition to golf, Troon specializes in homeowner association management, private residence clubs, estate management and associated hospitality venues. Troonâs award-winning food and beverage division operates and manages 600-plus food and beverage operations located at golf resorts, private clubs, daily fee golf courses and recreational facilities. Troonâs family of brands includes Troon Golf, Troon PrivÃ©, Troon International, Indigo Sports, CADDIE MASTER, ClubUp, Cliff Drysdale Tennis, True Club Solutions, RealFood Hospitality, Strategy and Design, ICON Management and Eventive Sports. For additional news and information, visit www.Troon.com . For additional information about our Catering Services or if you would like to rent one of our great banquet spaces, please submit an email that includes your name, event date, and a small description of your event to emily@secondplatecatering.com . Second Plate Catering Customer Reviews Dear Heather, Thank you so much for making arrangements for the ladies of Stoney Pointe to have their Christmas Luncheon in the Sawgrass Room. The room was beautifully decorated and the food was delicious. Our server, Holly, was excellent. She was very attentive without being intrusive. All of the feedback and comments I have heard have been very good. Several talked about coming back with their husbands and others spoke of getting the “girls” together for a night out. I think you have a great location for our neighborhood and wish you success. Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year! Kathy Fry Stoney Pointe HOA 12/15/19 The Heights Download the PDF Primary Sidebar Restaurant and Lounge Rentals and Catering Rental & Catering Form Copyright © 2025 Cleveland Heights Golf Course All Rights Reserved. DONATE NEWSLETTERS Sign In Open Search Search for: Search ♡ DONATE Menu Sign In NEWS Open dropdown menu HOME A & E Business City Hall COVID-19 Downtown Dining Health Insight Polk Neighborhoods People Politics Open dropdown menu Voter Guide Public Safety Recreation Schools Sports Transportation COMMUNITY Open dropdown menu Newcomers’ Guide Community Forums Find a locally owned restaurant near you Info Maps Weather EVENTS Open dropdown menu Candid Conversations 2025 All Events Music Calendar Add an event OBITUARIES Open dropdown menu Obituaries Submit an Obituary ABOUT Open dropdown menu Newsletters Add LkldNow to Your Phone About Us Staff and Board Members Policies Open dropdown menu Conflict of Interest Policy Editorial Independence Policy Donor, Sponsorship, Advertising Policy Privacy Policy Terms of Service SUPPORT US Open dropdown menu Donate Sponsorships Our Donors Posted in Business New Irish Pub at Cleveland Heights Clubhouse Brews Hope by Marilyn Meyer July 17, 2019 Updated August 9, 2022 Share this: Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Facebook Click to share on Nextdoor (Opens in new window) Nextdoor Click to share on Bluesky (Opens in new window) Bluesky Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window) Email Click to print (Opens in new window) Print An Irish pub anchors the new restaurant-catering service at Cleveland Heights Golf Course, and city officials are optimistic that their fourth private partner providing clubhouse cuisine will be their lucky charm. Keep up with what’s happening in Lakeland with only one email a week. Sign up Today is the soft opening for 1916 Irish Pub at the Cleveland Heights clubhouse. It’s modeled after a business by the same name in Plant City . That’s because there’s common ownership. Chuck Jamieson of Seffner, part owner of Plant City’s 1916, is also 80 percent owner of J&M Gulf Coast , which won the city of Lakeland’s contract to run the food operation at Cleveland Heights after being the only company responding when the city sought vendors. Jamieson is also part owner of Second Plate Catering in Plant City and was a founding partner of Duke’s Brewhouse , which now has locations in Plant City, Lakeland and Winter Haven. The three previous contracts the city had with restaurateurs over the last few years ended earlier than expected because of financial difficulties. Jamieson, 44, said he has an extensive background in food and beverage service and in golf course operations. He started his career at Old Memorial Golf Club in Tampa, where he spent about 10 years, he said. He, along with two co-workers then branched out to start Duke’s Brewhouse  in Plant City. In 2016, they opened 1916 Irish Pub, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Ireland’s struggle to break free from England’s rule, he said. Cleveland Heights Clubhouse, viewed from the southeast He has plans to return Cleveland Heights’ restaurant to its historic role as not only a stop for golfers but a neighborhood dining spot and a venue for weddings, bridal and baby showers, birthdays and other celebrations. Only about one-third of the 10,000 square-foot space is being used by the restaurant/bar, Jamieson said. In addition to the main dining room/bar area, there are two other rooms and a veranda that together can accommodate about 300 people for catered events provided through Second Plate Catering, he said. Founded in 1923, Cleveland Heights Golf Course and its clubhouse “was a staple of the neighborhood for generations,” Jamieson said. And it will be again, Jamieson said. “We are going to spend thousands to make it an event space competitive with what is available elsewhere in Lakeland, even in Tampa and Orlando,” he said. “As people build new memories, they will embrace it and it will again be a legacy place,” Jamieson said. Soft opening Following the closure of Bosko’s Clubhouse Grille about two weeks ago, there will be a soft re-opening of the restaurant today with a limited 1916 Irish Pub menu and beverages, mostly to provide services for golfers, Jamieson said. The city has committed $5,000 to replace carpeting and paint the interior during the next 30 days, said Bob Donahay, city parks and recreation director. And Jamieson already has installed flat-screen TVs above the bar, he said. Eventually, the menu will duplicate that of his 1916 Irish Pub at 2309 Thonotosassa Road in Plant City, Jamieson said. There, beverages include soft drinks, craft beers and cocktails, along with Irish beers and whiskey. The food menu features sandwiches – including a Reuben, a corned beef and an Irish stew sandwich – a variety of flatbreads and small plates that range from salads to shepherd’s pie and smoked fish spread or a hummus platter. Financial loses The city-owned golf course has taken a big financial hit this past year while the mid-century irrigation system was replaced and a force main line is under construction, Donahay said. During a budget meeting Monday, city officials discussed the amount of park department subsidies that keep Cleveland Heights operating and what can be done in the long term to drop the planned $1.1 million subsidy in the 2020-2021 budget back to the $800,000 subsidy before the irrigation project started. Mayor Bill Mutz said the eventual goal is to create enough success over the next few years drop the annual subsidy to $500,000. Contribute Now Donahay said that could be done through a combination of increased use of the 27-hole course and increased rents made possible by success of the restaurant/catering business and its beverage cart service on the golf course. But, Donahay said, city commissioners and the public need to understand that there is no golf course in Polk County that makes money on its own. Across the country, golf courses are subsidized, whether by government funds, homeowner associations, club dues or other means, he said. “We are going to do all we can to make it the best course around,” Donahay said. “But it is a park. We subsidize all our parks – the tennis courts and Common Ground across the street, Kelly Rec Center, Lake Parker Park.” Even with improvements at the Cleveland Heights course and at various other courses around the county, “Polk County golf is still Polk County golf,” Donahay said. “If the fee gets over two $20 bills, people go somewhere else. People shop. You make your money January through the middle of April.” Recognizing that there is always a summer slump in restaurant revenue from golfers, the city will give Jamieson a break on rent each May through September. Restaurant lease The five-year lease on the clubhouse began Monday and has three additional five-year options. To get started, J & M will not pay rent for July, August or September, then will pay $4,500 a month for October and November. Next January through April the rent will be $4,750 a month, then will drop to $2,500 a month, returning to $4,750 monthly in October through the rest of the year. Beginning in January 2021, the rent will be $5,000 a month during the busy fall, winter and early spring then drop to $3,000 a month during the slack summer season. In January 2025, the contract amounts will be renegotiated. Under the terms of the lease, the restaurant/bar must be open at least 60 hours a week and provide two meals daily – lunch and dinner. It will continue to provide services at various charitable golf tournaments, receiving corkage fees. During the budget hearing, Commissioner Phillip Walker asked why the city staff expects Jamieson to be successful operating the restaurant when the three previous operators were unable to make it financially. Donahay said that Jamieson has extensive experience in restaurant and bar operations, catering and golf courses and has a defined business plan that will tap into the special events market. Already, Jamieson has started advertising, something the previous tenant did not do, and has installed sports bar TVs, he said. “This is not his first rodeo,” Donahay said. Commissioner Stephanie Madden wanted assurances that the waitresses would not be wearing the skimpy costumes used at some of Jamieson’s other establishments. Donahay said that has been covered and Jamieson understands this is a family-friendly neighborhood spot. Commissioners unanimously passed the lease agreement Monday afternoon. Tagged: lkldnow Join the Conversation 7 Comments Patrick Walley says: July 17, 2019 at 10:53 am The addition of a disc golf course to the existing ball golf course would most certainly help to increase greens fee revenue. Reply Kim Schell says: July 19, 2019 at 7:01 am I’ve thought the same. Disc Golf is growing and would serve a different demagraphic. The course out south is a nod to the sport but only that as it is heavily wooded and maintained by volunteers. Reply Linda Hite says: July 18, 2019 at 9:28 am I love having lunch there. The view for an hour outside is so relaxing.  So many people were unaware you could have lunch there; glad to see some advertisement. I would like to see entertainment and dancing come back there like we did there and other places for 10 years. Lakeland lacks places for middle age to older adults to congregate and dance. Even if there is a small cover charge and snacks to purchase, people would come.  Thank you and wish you much success.. Reply Randy Borden says: July 19, 2019 at 8:19 am I don’t think the course down south offers a beverage cart either. Reply David Cook says: July 19, 2019 at 12:38 pm I agree with Patrick, adding a disc golf course to the grounds would be a great addition of revenue during the year. There’s quite a few golf/ disc golf course’s popping up over the country. There’s one in Jacksonville called New World sports complex & it has both that co-habitat the grounds. Reply David Cook says: July 20, 2019 at 1:55 am I agree with Patrick on adding a disc golf course to the grounds as an added source of revenue for the year. There are quite a few course’s popping up around the country that have golf & disc co-habitatating the grounds. For instance there is a course up in Jacksonville that has an 18 hole golf course & 2 18 hole disc golf course’s that share the same land. The place is called New World sports complex. Reply Ramona Terrio says: July 20, 2019 at 10:12 am The heights is our second home hope this does well hope they kept some of our favorites.(patron and pork rinds) looking forward to hang with all our friends again, Best of luck !!
